raw_text:
Chelsea ridiculed over complaint
 
 Barcelona assistant coach Henk Ten Cate has branded Chelsea's expected complaint to Uefa as "pathetic".
 
 The Blues are poised to complain about an alleged half-time incident during Wednesday's 2-1 loss at the Nou Camp. The source of Chelsea's anger was an alleged talk between Barca boss Frank Rijkaard and referee Anders Frisk, who later dismissed Didier Drogba. "To react the way Chelsea have is pathetic. Mourinho lied with the line-ups, and now this," Ten Cate said. Uefa has said its own tunnel representative witnessed nothing unusual out of the ordinary during the half-time break. Spokesman William Gaillard said: "Frisk says Rijkaard greeted him and apologised he had not had the opportunity to say hello before the game. "We had two Uefa officials there and neither witnessed it. The referee's dressing room was locked and he and his assistants were the only people allowed in." Indeed, it is the Londoners who could be on the receiving end of any punishment after failing to turn up for the compulsory press conference after the defeat.
 
 Uefa delegate Thomas Giordano added: "The only unusual thing that happened as far as we are concerned is that Chelsea failed to present themselves in the press conference." The referee is not expected to include any of the alleged incidents in his report to Uefa - weakening Chelsea's case. Rijkaard was critical of Mourinho's decision not to speak to the media after the match. "There was a lot of talking before the game and now surprisingly there is a lot of talking after the game. It is not good behaviour after a match," he said. "Maybe they want to start something and make it worse than than it is. I really don't understand it. I am very calm about it."
 
 Barca midfielder Deco, formerly managed by Mourinho at Porto, agreed that it was not typical of his fellow Portuguese to lodge a protest. "It's not normal behaviour on his part. It was not logical he did not give a news conference," he said. Rijkaard added: "Chelsea is the team which has conceded fewest goals in the English league and they defend very well so I am very pleased with the win. "My men deserved victory and I am pleased to have won this match. I congratulate my players."
llama3.2:1b: Chelsea's assistant coach Henk Ten Cate described the expected complaint to Uefa as "pathetic" after Barcelona's Frank Rijkaard criticized Chelsea for reacting poorly to an alleged half-time incident. Barca officials, including referee Anders Frisk and their tunnel representative, witnessed nothing unusual during the break.
llama3.2:3b: Chelsea expected to complain to Uefa about a half-time incident, but Barca assistant coach Henk Ten Cate says their complaint is "pathetic". Uefa officials witnessed nothing unusual during the half-time break, and the referee's report is unlikely to include any alleged incidents. Rijkaard criticized Chelsea for not speaking to the media after the match, and Barcelona midfielder Deco said it was not typical of Mourinho's behavior.
gemma2:2b: Chelsea intends to complain to UEFA about an alleged incident during their match against Barcelona.  Barça's assistant coach, Henk Ten Cate, has criticized Chelsea's potential complaint as "pathetic," stating that the team is likely engaging in a fabricated protest after failing to show up for the required press conference following the game. Uefa officials have stated that they witnessed no unusual activity during the half-time break and that the referee's report lacks evidence of any misconduct. Barcelona manager, Frank Rijkaard, expressed his disappointment at Chelsea’s behavior, stating it is typical of a team looking to escalate an issue, while also highlighting their victory.  Barça midfielder Deco added that this type of protest was not usual for Chelsea.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Barcelona assistant coach Henk Ten Cate accused Chelsea of using an alleged half-time incident, saying it was "pathetic" for the club to complain about it during their upcoming Uefa press conference. The referee Anders Frisk dismissed Didier Drogba's claim that Barca's players were deliberately speaking in a heated exchange without the referee noticing, while Rijkaard emphasized Chelsea's poor goal-scoring record and defense capabilities. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho was criticized for not addressing the media after winning the match, with Mourinho stating he "wanted to start something worse than this".
qwen2.5:1.5b: Barcelona assistant Henk Ten Cate ridicules Chelsea's complaint to Uefa over alleged half-time incident, criticizing the team for lying about line-up changes and reacting poorly due to Mourinho's actions post-match. Uefa spokesperson William Gaillard disputes claims of unusual events during halftime, with referee Anders Frisk denying witnessing any incidents that led to Chelsea missing their press conference afterward. Barca manager Rijkaard defends his side's win, praising their performance in defense despite conceding few goals this season.
qwen2.5:3b: Assistant coach Henk Ten Cate of Barcelona branded Chelsea's expected complaint to UEFA over an alleged half-time incident during their 2-1 loss as "pathetic". Chelsea, who are expected to complain about Frank Rijkaard and referee Anders Frisk allegedly talking during the break, claim Mourinho lied with his line-ups. Uefa denies any unusual occurrence at halftime; they state two of its representatives were present but did not witness anything. Chelsea can be punished for failing to attend their mandatory press conference after the game. UEFA delegate Thomas Giordano confirmed only Chelsea's failure to appear in a press conference was noted, weakening Chelsea's case. Rijkaard criticized Mourinho’s lack of media presence post-match and Deco concurred that it wasn't typical behavior from Mourinho.
opencoder:1.5b: The text summarizes the incident of Chelsea against Barcelona, where they both praised Uefa's officials who dismissed the alleged talk between Barca boss Frank Rijkaard and referee Anders Frisk. They also pointed out an unusual event in the match which may have had a negative impact on them. The presenter added that it was not a normal behaviour for players to raise a protest after winning a game.
smollm:1.7b:
The Blues' complaint about a half-time incident during their loss at Barcelona is pathetic, as it seems to be based on hearsay and lacks any concrete evidence or credible sources. The Blues' source of anger was an alleged talk between Frank Rijkaard and Didier Drogba, which they later dismissed. The Blues' complaint about the lack of a press conference after their loss is also pathetic, as it seems to be based on speculation rather than actual facts.

The Blues' complaint about the lack of evidence for their alleged half-time incident is particularly pathetic, as it seems to be based on hearsay and lacks any concrete evidence or credible sources. The Blues are complaining over a potential half-time event involving Frank Rijkaard and Anders Frisk. Uefa said they didn't witness anything unusual during the break but expected more in their report. Thomas Giordano added that Chelsea's poor performance meant they deserve victory, while Rijkaard criticized Mourinho for missing media after the game. tinyllama:1.1b: The UEFA vice-president William Gaillard has slammed the complaint made by Barcelona assistant coach Henk Ten Cate over the alleged half-time incident in their Premier League defeat against Manchester United. He called it "pathetic" and criticized Ri Jinjkarad, the other UEFA representative there, for not being able to witness anything unusual during the break. The club's official delegate Thomas Giordano also stated that Uefa has been made aware of the alleged incident but will not pursue a punishment. Meanwhile, Ri Jijkaard was critical of Mourinho's decision not to speak to the media and believes it is not good behavior to have such an impact on matchday. Despite this, Ten Cate expressed his dissatisfaction with the outcome, stating that he was happy with the win but felt the team should have gained a more significant lead.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Chelsea complained against the referee, Uefa delegates, and their manager, Frank Rijkaard, for not providing a fair review of a game against FC Barcelona. The Blues argued that they were not given an equal chance to defend their lead during halftime. The Spanish side dismissed this claim by stating that it was actually Didier Drogba who initiated the conversation with Frisk, who later ended up disinviting the Blues' manager to the press conference after the game. Despite Mourinho's tactics, Chelsea is still expected to receive a punishment from Uefa, which could include fines or sanctions.
phi:2.7b: The text discusses Chelsea's expected complaint against Barca for an alleged incident during their game. Barcelona's assistant coach, Henk Ten Cate, criticizes Chelsea's reaction as "pathetic," while Uefa's witness reports no unusual activity out of the ordinary. Rijkaard, the referee, claims that he and his assistants were the only ones present in Chelsea's dressing room, and Uefa has not received any evidence of foul play from them. Barca's Deco agrees with Ten Cate and believes Mourinho's decision not to speak to the media is not typical behavior for a Portuguese coach. The referee, however, defends Chelsea's actions and claims that he deserved victory in the game.

The Blues are poised to complain about an alleged half-time incident during Wednesday's 2-1 loss at the Nou Camp where allegedly an alleged talk between Barca boss Frank Rijkaard and referee Anders Frisk was witnessed by Uefa's own tunnel representative. Chelsea is expected to fail to turn up for a compulsory press conference after the defeat. The Londoners are not expected to include any of the alleged incidents in their report to Uefa, weakening their case. Barca midfielder Deco agreed that it was not typical of Jose Mourinho's behavior, and Rijkaard praised his team's performance in a victory.
